comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content:
Weehawken grain elevator explosion

Grain Elevator Blown Up‎.
The Baltimore Sun - July 16, 1915
New York, July 15. An explosion today wrecked a big grain elevator in Weehawken. across the Hudson river from New York, and severely injured a half dozen ...

comment.author: 12500923@N04
comment._content: Thanks Richard.  That explains the missing wall.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of October 25, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0810FA395D16738... indicates that there were arrests (of Robert Fay and Walter Scholz) made in relation to the explosion, "BOMB FACTORY IN HIS ROOM; Prisoner, an Officer in the Kaiser's Army, Carried Map of Harbor. MECHANIC AID ALSO TAKEN Kept High-Power Automobile and Motor Boat, Always Ready for Fast Service. A NEW INFERNAL MACHINE Telescope Device Found in Lodgings, with Supply of Most Powerful Explosive."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The Literary Digest, Volume 51 books.google.com/books?id=zA4xAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA993&l... has more on the suspected bomb plots. Information Annual books.google.com/books?id=g8dPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA226&l... indicates that Fay and Scholz (plus some others) were found guilty and sentenced to prison in Atlanta. Note: searches on "Robert Fay Walter Scholz" yield lots of hits in newspapers and digitized volumes.

comment.author: 12500923@N04
comment._content: Wow. Thanks for the research.  In will look them up.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks, everyone, for figuring out the location of the photo and the circumstances. Fascinating!  We'll add information to the description when we next update.
